lines.text: I've seen dogs that wouldn't claim you for a son, Tate.
I've been mixed up in a lot of things, Tate, but up to now, I've never been hired for my guns.
Can you afford to be so particular?
Here's the item we were talking about the other day. I think you'll find it satisfactory.
United States dollars are usually satisfactory, aren't they?
Your cut will be $10,000.
What do I have to do to earn it?
Lufton's tough and my ranchers aren't. You make up the difference.
Did you ever notice how them four always stick together?
Why not? Reardon and Shotten work for Riling, and Garry's a friend that just came in to help.
I can buy me that kind of friend for $75 a month and no questions asked.
Shotten, Reardon, and me. Hired gunmen.
Shotten and Reardon get paid in gold eagles. You get paid in thousands.
Yeah. Only difference between us is the price.
It's about your son, Barden. He was killed in the raid.
I figured maybe that's what happened when he didn't come home.
I was with him when he got hit. Nothing I could do.
Big price to pay for a little bit of grass.

It starts with your double-cross of a bunch of jug-headed farmers and the hiring of gun hands. It goes on to your making love to a man's daughter to get her to turn against her own father, and your try for Lufton today. It's past that, to the death of Kris Barden's son, and it winds up right here, with Reardon waiting outside to see if I go with you, or if he shoots me in the back.

[after Barden kills Reardon]
Why did you do it?
I always wanted to shoot one of you. He was the handiest.
